category_summary:
AI coding agents dominated discussions with extraordinary practitioner evidence. **Anthropic's bcherny** [revealed](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-3224ccef215a) the Claude Code team ships 100% AI-generated code using **Opus 4.5**, sparking intense debate about the future of software development. **Simon Willison** [highlighted](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-f428962b7742) a fully AI-built 20,000-line Rust browser, while **Ethan Mollick** demonstrated Claude Code creating complete adventure games from single prompts.

- **Washington Post** [broke major investigation](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-1849acd242a9) into AI companies' secret race to ingest copyrighted works, with **Anthropic's Project Panama** attempting a more ethical approach
- **OpenAI** [launched **Prism**](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-ec5a74493236), a free LaTeX workspace for scientific collaboration, drawing massive engagement (2.4M views)
- **AI2** [released **SERA**](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-38bad42c37d5), open-source coding agents reproducible for ~$400, democratizing agent development
- **Google** [announced **Agentic Vision**](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-d7e7120ebcc1) for Gemini 3 Flash; **Anthropic** [partnered with UK government](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-4259e2cbcec7) for citizen services

**John Carmack** [provided technical analysis](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-486f93d55e1a) comparing biological and artificial neural networks, while **Yann LeCun** [defended his JEPA research](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-e2c324072cae) productivity and announced company formation around world models. **Nathan Lambert** [predicted](/?date=2026-01-28&category=social#item-0f9ad961124d) academic paper writing will be transformed by AI in 2026, noting intense competition for Overleaf.

items.title:
@karpathy As always, a very thoughtful and well reasoned take. I read till the end.

I think the Cla...
items.content:
@karpathy As always, a very thoughtful and well reasoned take. I read till the end.

I think the Claude Code team itself might be an  indicator of where things are headed. We have directional answers for some (not all) of the prompts:

1. We hire mostly generalists. We have a mix of senior engineers and less senior since not all of the things people learned in the past translate to coding with LLMs. As you said, the model can fill in the details. 10x engineers definitely exist, and they often span across multiple areas ‚Äî product and design, product and business, product and infra (@jarredsumner is a great example of the latter. Yes, he‚Äôs blushing).
2. Pretty much 100% of our code is written by Claude Code + Opus 4.5. For me personally it has been 100% for two+ months now, I don‚Äôt even make small edits by hand. I shipped 22 PRs yesterday and 27 the day before, each one 100% written by Claude. Some were written from a CLI, some from the iOS app; others on the team code largely with the Claude Code app Slack or with the Desktop app. I think most of the industry will see similar stats in the coming months ‚Äî it will take more time for some vs others. We will then start seeing similar stats for non-coding computer work also.
3. The code quality problems you listed are real: the model over-complicates things, it leaves dead code around, it doesn‚Äôt like to refactor when it should. These will continue improve as the model improves, and our code quality bar will go up even more as a result. My bet is that there will be no slopcopolypse because the model will become better at writing less sloppy code and at fixing existing code issues; I think 4.5 is already quite good at these and it will continue to get better. In the meantime, what helps is also having the model code review its code using a fresh context window; at Anthropic we use claude -p for this on every PR and it catches and fixes many issues. 

Overall your ideas very much resonate. Thanks again for sharing. ‚úåÔ∏è

items.content_html:
@karpathy As always, a very thoughtful and well reasoned take. I read till the end.

I think the Claude Code team itself might be an indicator of where things are headed. We have directional answers for some (not all) of the prompts:

1. We hire mostly generalists. We have a mix of senior engineers and less senior since not all of the things people learned in the past translate to coding with LLMs. As you said, the model can fill in the details. 10x engineers definitely exist, and they often span across multiple areas ‚Äî product and design, product and business, product and infra (@jarredsumner is a great example of the latter. Yes, he‚Äôs blushing).

2. Pretty much 100% of our code is written by Claude Code + Opus 4.5. For me personally it has been 100% for two+ months now, I don‚Äôt even make small edits by hand. I shipped 22 PRs yesterday and 27 the day before, each one 100% written by Claude. Some were written from a CLI, some from the iOS app; others on the team code largely with the Claude Code app Slack or with the Desktop app. I think most of the industry will see similar stats in the coming months ‚Äî it will take more time for some vs others. We will then start seeing similar stats for non-coding computer work also.

3. The code quality problems you listed are real: the model over-complicates things, it leaves dead code around, it doesn‚Äôt like to refactor when it should. These will continue improve as the model improves, and our code quality bar will go up even more as a result. My bet is that there will be no slopcopolypse because the model will become better at writing less sloppy code and at fixing existing code issues; I think 4.5 is already quite good at these and it will continue to get better. In the meantime, what helps is also having the model code review its code using a fresh context window; at Anthropic we use claude -p for this on every PR and it catches and fixes many issues.

Overall your ideas very much resonate. Thanks again for sharing. ‚úåÔ∏è

items.title: Introducing Agentic Vision ‚Äî a new frontier AI capability in Gemini 3 Flash that converts image unde...
items.content:
Introducing Agentic Vision ‚Äî a new frontier AI capability in Gemini 3 Flash that converts image understanding from a static act into an agentic process.

By combining visual reasoning with code execution, one of the first tools supported by Agentic Vision, the model grounds answers in visual evidence and delivers a consistent 5-10% quality boost across most vision benchmarks. Here‚Äôs how the agentic ‚ÄòThink, Act, Observe‚Äô loop works:
‚Äî Think: The model analyzes an image query then architects a multi-step plan
‚Äî Act: The model then generates and executes Python code to actively manipulate or analyze images
‚Äî Observe: The transformed image is appended to the model's context window, allowing it to inspect the new data before generating a final response to the initial image query 

Learn more about Agentic Vision and how to access it in our blog ‚¨áÔ∏è
https://t.co/UdSOuF2YXY

items.title: @yunta_tsai You can argue that bio brains have vastly more weights that are mostly sparse, because t...
items.content:
@yunta_tsai You can argue that bio brains have vastly more weights that are mostly sparse, because the space of neurons that could have been connected to is very large, with synapses exploring and getting pruned. Simulating bio connectivity would be expensive on GPUs!

Bio neurons look good at the worm level, where mere hundreds seem to do more work than artificial ones could, but it seems like artificial networks may have better scaling properties in the billions.

items.summary: John Carmack provides technical analysis comparing biological vs artificial neural networks, discussing sparse weights, connectivity costs, and scaling properties - noting bio neurons perform better at small scale (worms) but artificial networks may scale better at billions of parameters

Bio neurons look good at the worm level, where mere hundreds seem to do more work than artificial ones could, but it seems like artificial networks may have better scaling properties in the billions.

vLLM day-0 support is ready. If you're building multimodal agents, this one's worth evaluating:

‚Ä¢ Vision-native: Pre-trained on 15T vision-language tokens, not a bolted-on encoder
‚Ä¢ Code from vision: Feed it UI designs or video workflows, get working code
‚Ä¢ Agent Swarm: Breaks complex tasks into parallel sub-agents automatically

items.title: These behaviors from Chinese models thinking they‚Äôre built by American companies has a very large po...
items.content:
These behaviors from Chinese models thinking they‚Äôre built by American companies has a very large policy impact. It reinforces the theory that Chinese models are only good because they distill from closed western models. 

Distillation from API models definitely helps Chinese models ‚Äî especially in a compute crunch for training ‚Äî but cutting off this behavior would not change the nature of the Chinese open ecosystem much at all. 

In fact, Chinese builders could improve each others models even more if forced to distill from them. I don‚Äôt expect this to happen, there are just too many strong api models out there and it makes for a very nice workflow for doing post training data synthesis. 

TLDR maybe model builders should put a bit more effort into identity though (myself included).
items.author: @natolambert

Argues distillation from Western APIs helps Chinese models but cutting it off wouldn't change ecosystem much - Chinese builders could improve by distilling from each other.
items.reasoning: Important policy analysis from recognized AI researcher. High engagement (456 likes, 90K views). Addresses significant geopolitical and technical AI ecosystem dynamics.

Argues distillation from Western APIs helps Chinese models but cutting it off wouldn't change ecosystem much - Chinese builders could improve by distilling from each other.

Distillation from API models definitely helps Chinese models ‚Äî especially in a compute crunch for training ‚Äî but cutting off this behavior would not change the nature of the Chinese open ecosystem much at all.

In fact, Chinese builders could improve each others models even more if forced to distill from them. I don‚Äôt expect this to happen, there are just too many strong api models out there and it makes for a very nice workflow for doing post training data synthesis.

items.title:
Ok, when I see myself accused of bullshitting, I fight back.

Me saying that you should stop reading...
items.content:
Ok, when I see myself accused of bullshitting, I fight back.

Me saying that you should stop reading AI-generated code isn't just some clickbait or hot take you are used to on this platform.

When I'm saying something, it's based on knowledge, hands-on experience, and thinking, a lot of thinking.

Why should we all stop reading AI-generated code? It's because of how the machine generating it was built.

Take Claude in particular. This isn't a vanilla LLM. It's a system that was finetuned end-to-end to maximize reward using a reinforcement learning algorithm.

The reward is assigned by a script. The script breaks working code, asks Claude to fix it, and Claude can use tools such as grep and python to get this reward.

Claude doesn't care about the beauty of the code, there's no reward for this. Claude cares about getting a high reward from this script that broke the code. Therefore it needs to come up with working code.

The script that decides whether code works runs code, sees the output, compares it to the expected output, and returns reward. There's no beauty of code in its logic, because it's a script. If the output is the same as expected, the script returns 1. If it isn't, the script returns 0. The script will optionally subtract from the reward the number of tokens used by Claude to come to the solution.

What does that mean for us humans? Claude will generate whatever gets it this reward, and it will try to get it by using the fewest tokens possible.

Therefore, if it gets it a higher reward, Claude will generate an ugly mess. As long as this mess is short and it works, Claude is happy.

So, yes, stop reading AI-generated code.

Currently, Anthropic might have some part of the reward that honors some notion of readability. But they only do that because there are still coders who aren't ready to move on.

But the industry will move on; it already is moving on, and Anthropic will remove this "readability" reward component, because having it hurts performance.

Why? Because if you are something of a scientist yourself, you know that you cannot optimize multiple objectives at the same time, so you either maximize the chance for code to run, or you minimize the number of used tokens, or you maximize the readability.

Which one of the three do you think the industry really cares about?
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Andriy Burkov provides detailed technical argument for why developers should stop reading AI-generated code, explaining how Claude's RL training optimizes for working code with minimal tokens, not readability.

items.title:
Will our courts have AI witnesses? 
¬†
AI witnesses are AI systems that turn logs and sensor data suc...
items.content:
Will our courts have AI witnesses? 
¬†
AI witnesses are AI systems that turn logs and sensor data such as car crash records, phone traces, building access logs, and video into a timeline and reconstruction that can influence court cases and arbitration. 

Supporters see faster, clearer fact finding, while critics worry about false certainty, bias, unequal access to data and experts, and the need for strict standards around data custody, error rates, transparency, and meaningful challenges in court.

@IrenaCronin and I write this newsletter every week and this is this week's topic.

Read for free and subscribe: https://t.co/HHwYy7NoAl

items.title: Here's my conversation with @latkins and the team at @arcee_ai on their path to training and releasi...
items.content:
Here's my conversation with @latkins and the team at @arcee_ai on their path to training and releasing Trinity Large today. 

From going all in on open models built end to end in the US 6 months ago to having the model in hand is no easy feet.

I loved this conversation on how to design a startup around open models and take a bold step to scale it up. I'm openly an Arcee fan, watching them take risk and pull it off.

We discuss:
- The state (and future) of open vs. closed models,
- The business of selling open models for on-prem deployments,
- The story of Arcee AI & going ‚Äúall-in‚Äù on this training run,
- The ATOM project,
- Building frontier model training teams in 6 months,
- and other great topics. I really loved this one, and think you well too.

Chapters:
00:00:00 Intro: Arcee AI, Trinity Models & Trinity Large
00:08:26 Transitioning a Company to Pre-training
00:13:00 Technical Decisions: Muon and MoE
00:18:41 Scaling and MoE Training Pain
00:23:14 Post-training and RL Strategies
00:28:09 Team Structure and Data Scaling
00:31:31 The Trinity Manifesto: US Open Weights
00:42:31 Specialized Models and Distillation
00:47:12 Infrastructure and Hosting 400B
00:50:53 Open Source as a Business Moat
00:56:31 Predictions: Best Model in 2026
01:02:29 Lightning Round & Conclusions

More great open model builder podcasts coming soon!

items.content_html:

But the vast majority are using LLM-derived methods, like VLA, or diffusion policies with RL fine-tuning in simulation. Nice for narrow tasks.

The companies building humanoid hardware don't tend to be the ones working on innovative robotics AI.

items.title:
Terminals : LaTex :: AI for Coding : AI for Science

when Claude Code started it was just a humble C...
items.content:
Terminals : LaTex :: AI for Coding : AI for Science

when Claude Code started it was just a humble CLI side project. today it forms the basis for Claude Cowork, a general purpose non-coding desktop agent. I see a lot more patterns like this happening - things start from humble origins, but the general capability of the models start enabling a lot more.

the shorthand for @OpenAI's new Prism is going to be "its Cursor for Scientists" or "it's Overleaf with AI". but to. me the "wow moment" of this pod was when @kevinweil just casually generated well structured lecture notes for general relativity to restructure the same information in a new light.

Prism shows a glimpse of the future in AI for Science EDUCATION as much as it does AI for Science publication and communication itself. It also is a useful case study in the general "AI tools for thought" space ‚Äî if you want to see what a good "Cursor for X" domain looks like, OpenAI now has an answer.
items.author: @swyx
items.summary: swyx discusses OpenAI's new Prism product as 'Cursor for Scientists', highlighting its potential for AI in science education and research, comparing it to how Claude Code evolved from CLI to desktop agent.

when Claude Code started it was just a humble CLI side project. today it forms the basis for Claude Cowork, a general purpose non-coding desktop agent. I see a lot more patterns like this happening - things start from humble origins, but the general capability of the models start enabling a lot more.

the shorthand for @OpenAI's new Prism is going to be "its Cursor for Scientists" or "it's Overleaf with AI". but to. me the "wow moment" of this pod was when @kevinweil just casually generated well structured lecture notes for general relativity to restructure the same information in a new light.

Prism shows a glimpse of the future in AI for Science EDUCATION as much as it does AI for Science publication and communication itself. It also is a useful case study in the general "AI tools for thought" space ‚Äî if you want to see what a good "Cursor for X" domain looks like, OpenAI now has an answer.

items.title: LobeChat is an open-source, multi-model interface with 70,000 GitHub stars, 14,000 forks, and 6 mill...
items.content:
LobeChat is an open-source, multi-model interface with 70,000 GitHub stars, 14,000 forks, and 6 million users.

It's really, really good!

Now, they turned it into @lobehub to solve one of the problems that I've had with every other agent platform.

Every platform treats agents as disposable: You spin one up, it does a task, you throw it away.

This is fine for simple stuff, but it doesn't scale to anything more complex.

LobeHub is introducing something new: agents as teammates.

You build agent groups that work together.

‚Ä¢ A supervisor agent orchestrates every workflow
‚Ä¢ Individual agents handle specialized tasks
‚Ä¢ These agents work in parallel
‚Ä¢ Agents can challenge and cross-check each other

The team ran one sample on both LobeHub and Manus:

‚Ä¢ LobeHub took 2:58 minutes, $0.46 average cost
‚Ä¢ Manus took 9:01 minutes, $2.98 average cost

That's 3x faster and 6.5x cheaper!

The difference here is that Manus uses VM-based web browsing, while LobeHub connects directly to source files.

A few things that stand out:

‚Ä¢ LobeHub supports any model: Claude, Gemini, or whatever you want.

‚Ä¢ LobeHub uses human-in-the-loop by default. You confirm before agents execute.

‚Ä¢ You can discover and use agent groups that others have built.

When testing LobeHub Desktop and Claude Cowork, they appear to have very similar performance. LobeHub has the advantage of routing tasks to multiple models, giving it an edge.

For example, Claude Cowork couldn't extract the subtitles of a video, but LobeHub did because it routed the task to Gemini.

The attached video shows LobeHub tailoring a resume for different job positions. A bunch of agents work in parallel to generate different versions of the resume.

items.summary: Detailed review of LobeHub, comparing it to Manus for multi-agent orchestration. Claims 3x faster and 6.5x cheaper than Manus. Introduces concept of 'agents as teammates' with supervisor orchestration.

items.title:
Voice agents are awkward, and everyone notices:

You ask a question.
The agent thinks.
You wait.
And...
items.content:
Voice agents are awkward, and everyone notices:

You ask a question.
The agent thinks.
You wait.
And wait...

Nobody wants this. I'd rather talk to a person.

If your model's response time is over 300ms, you won't make it.

Unfortunately, most text-to-speech models can't get anywhere close to that.

I want you to take a look at the latest model released by @inworld_ai: TTS-1.5.

I built a simple voice agent using the model so you can see it in action and test it on your computer. You'll find the repository link below.

The latency numbers of this model are wild:

‚Ä¢ Max model ‚Üí under 250ms
‚Ä¢ Mini model ‚Üí under 130ms

That's 4x faster than prior generations and faster than human response times!

items.title:
Obviously, speed alone doesn't matter if the model sounds like a robot.

TTS-1.5 is currently #1 bot...
items.content:
Obviously, speed alone doesn't matter if the model sounds like a robot.

TTS-1.5 is currently #1 both on the Artificial Analysis TTS Leaderboard and Hugging Face's TTS Arena.

Here is what's happening behind the scenes:

1. Their new neural audio codec now uses a causal attention architecture. This allows them to stream in real time.

2. They used quantization-aware training for their model, which maintains output quality while reducing cost.

3. They are doing a lot of reinforcement learning post-training using DPO and GRPO to reduce hallucinations, fewer word cutoffs, no metallic artifacts, and get better expressiveness.

Here is the repository of the example I built:

https://t.co/4zyo6vpLVy

Thanks to the Inworld team for partnering with me on this post.

items.summary: Technical details on TTS-1.5: causal attention architecture for real-time streaming, quantization-aware training for cost reduction, DPO/GRPO reinforcement learning post-training to reduce hallucinations and improve expressiveness.

items.title:
some thoughts on naming AI products

naming is important, and has impact, especially on early virali...
items.content:
some thoughts on naming AI products

naming is important, and has impact, especially on early virality. babyagi was originally called "task-driven autonomous agent" and don't think it would have performed as well

autogpt had a more descriptive name, and had a lot more search queries as some also considered it the category name at the time (i remember people asking if babyagi was the first autogpt, which was confusing at first)

piggybacking on someone else's brand can be very powerful, but if you're too successful, will be asked to change names, and it can kill momentum. dalle mini became craiyon, claudeputer become codeputer, ai16z became elizaos, and clawdbot is now moltbot

there are a lot of naming approaches, and if you're not familiar and curious, search "igor naming guide" for some core buckets and considerations (i had gemini summarize the guide below)

when i'm coming up with a name for my projects, here's what i focus on:

(1) easy to remember (i usually go for silly),
(2) easy to pronounce, and
(3) easy to spell.
items.author: @yoheinakajima

items.reasoning: Thoughtful analysis from BabyAGI creator about AI product naming strategy with real examples. Practical insights for builders.

naming is important, and has impact, especially on early virality. babyagi was originally called "task-driven autonomous agent" and don't think it would have performed as well

autogpt had a more descriptive name, and had a lot more search queries as some also considered it the category name at the time (i remember people asking if babyagi was the first autogpt, which was confusing at first)

piggybacking on someone else's brand can be very powerful, but if you're too successful, will be asked to change names, and it can kill momentum. dalle mini became craiyon, claudeputer become codeputer, ai16z became elizaos, and clawdbot is now moltbot

there are a lot of naming approaches, and if you're not familiar and curious, search "igor naming guide" for some core buckets and considerations (i had gemini summarize the guide below)

when i'm coming up with a name for my projects, here's what i focus on:

items.title: Have you noticed a small detail? Every time DeepSeek releases a new model, they demo it with LobeCha...
items.content:
Have you noticed a small detail? Every time DeepSeek releases a new model, they demo it with LobeChat.

This popular open-source project already has 70k stars and 6M downloads. 

I‚Äôve been testing their new product @lobehub for a while, with help from its team, and it really feels like they‚Äôre taking the agent harness to the next level. In some scenarios, LobeHub delivers capabilities beyond Claude Cowork and Manus.

Last year, the exciting shift was models evolving from chat interfaces into action engines with tool use. So what‚Äôs next? 

One thing I‚Äôve noticed: today‚Äôs agents are still one-off, task-driven tools. Isolated, slow, costly, and hard to build. 

They fail to unlock the full potential of AI models. LobeHub changes that. It builds long-term agent teammates that grow with users. Anyone can easily create and collaborate with agent teams to deliver complex, end-to-end work. 

With multi-model support, LobeHub is faster, more cost-effective, and goes beyond single-agent systems.

True teammates. True teams.

For example, you can build a full X growth team to monitor trends, create content, schedule, and post.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer promotes LobeHub as next-gen agent platform, claiming it outperforms Manus and Claude Cowork in benchmarks - 1.5x faster, 4x cheaper, with multi-model support enabling agent teams that work end-to-end
items.reasoning: Detailed product comparison with specific metrics, but clearly promotional with invite code. Noteworthy for agent orchestration landscape tracking. High views (3.9K)

I‚Äôve been testing their new product @lobehub for a while, with help from its team, and it really feels like they‚Äôre taking the agent harness to the next level. In some scenarios, LobeHub delivers capabilities beyond Claude Cowork and Manus.

Last year, the exciting shift was models evolving from chat interfaces into action engines with tool use. So what‚Äôs next?

One thing I‚Äôve noticed: today‚Äôs agents are still one-off, task-driven tools. Isolated, slow, costly, and hard to build.

They fail to unlock the full potential of AI models. LobeHub changes that. It builds long-term agent teammates that grow with users. Anyone can easily create and collaborate with agent teams to deliver complex, end-to-end work.

With multi-model support, LobeHub is faster, more cost-effective, and goes beyond single-agent systems.

@arian_ghashghai I started the data problem interpretation. I'm not saying it is only about data, but that the entrepreneurs know that the AI breakthroughs, like what Yann is working on, will come and they need the data to feed in. We need both, obviously. We're all talking past each other. :-)

items.title: @tesla_archive @Tesla The thing people aren't realizing is that smoothness is what matters, and Tesl...
items.content:
@tesla_archive @Tesla The thing people aren't realizing is that smoothness is what matters, and Tesla's AI is smoother than all the others. That's how people are going to evaluate them.

Of course, safety and other factors are important, but the key is smoothness through:
1. Turns
2. Stop signs
3. Intersections

Then it's going to be about information, and Tesla's fleet is going to be a huge advantage as newer features (that haven't yet been considered) get rolled out. 

I don't see how anybody can match Tesla, even NVIDIA. They just don't have the fleet on the road, and by the time they do get a fleet on the road, Tesla's going to be way out in front again.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer argues Tesla's AI advantage is 'smoothness' in autonomous driving (turns, stops, intersections) and fleet data advantage is insurmountable - claims even NVIDIA can't match them
items.reasoning: Strong claims about Tesla FSD competitive positioning. Moderate engagement, subjective analysis
items.summary_html: Scobleizer argues Tesla's AI advantage is 'smoothness' in autonomous driving (turns, stops, intersections) and fleet data advantage is insurmountable - claims even NVIDIA can't match them
items.content_html:
@tesla_archive @Tesla The thing people aren't realizing is that smoothness is what matters, and Tesla's AI is smoother than all the others. That's how people are going to evaluate them.

Of course, safety and other factors are important, but the key is smoothness through:

1. Turns

2. Stop signs

3. Intersections

Then it's going to be about information, and Tesla's fleet is going to be a huge advantage as newer features (that haven't yet been considered) get rolled out.

I don't see how anybody can match Tesla, even NVIDIA. They just don't have the fleet on the road, and by the time they do get a fleet on the road, Tesla's going to be way out in front again.

items.title: Hours after Mike Isaac made this prediction, we're starting to see a trickle of CEO statements of th...
items.content:
Hours after Mike Isaac made this prediction, we're starting to see a trickle of CEO statements of the form "the President is strong and handsome, but lCE has gone too far"...

Threading the needle between placating employee sentiment and avoiding appearing critical of the boss

The reason they do it is understandable: as a high profile CEO any criticism of the President all but guarantees that the full power of the government will be used to retaliate against them and their company. They're hostages

Can't blame them really

items.title: I ran a difficult stock trading test vs Manus: ask agent to recommend trading strategies and execute...
items.content:
I ran a difficult stock trading test vs Manus: ask agent to recommend trading strategies and execute trades on behalf of the user.

Manus operates as a single agent and depends heavily on step-by-step user input. LobeHub runs from one command to the agent team: a supervisor coordinates agent teammates end to end, enabling near-automatic execution with minimal user intervention. Manus stays at L3. LobeHub moves agents to L4.

In addition, LobeHub beats Manus on speed, cost, and stability: 6m10s vs. 9m04s, $1.22 vs. $5.27. ~1.5√ó faster. ~4√ó cheaper.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer benchmarks LobeHub vs Manus on stock trading test - LobeHub completed in 6m10s vs 9m04s, cost $1.22 vs $5.27. Claims LobeHub operates at 'L4' autonomy vs Manus at 'L3'
items.reasoning: Specific benchmark data useful for comparing agent platforms, though promotional in nature
items.summary_html: Scobleizer benchmarks LobeHub vs Manus on stock trading test - LobeHub completed in 6m10s vs 9m04s, cost $1.22 vs $5.27. Claims LobeHub operates at 'L4' autonomy vs Manus at 'L3'
items.content_html:
I ran a difficult stock trading test vs Manus: ask agent to recommend trading strategies and execute trades on behalf of the user.

Manus operates as a single agent and depends heavily on step-by-step user input. LobeHub runs from one command to the agent team: a supervisor coordinates agent teammates end to end, enabling near-automatic execution with minimal user intervention. Manus stays at L3. LobeHub moves agents to L4.

In addition, LobeHub beats Manus on speed, cost, and stability: 6m10s vs. 9m04s, $1.22 vs. $5.27. ~1.5√ó faster. ~4√ó cheaper.

items.title: @agentsfy @eliebakouch The algorithm is there to serve the purposes of the xAI Corporation, not us. ...
items.content:
@agentsfy @eliebakouch The algorithm is there to serve the purposes of the xAI Corporation, not us. That's the real truth of the matter. 

Fixing it? Yeah, it'll get better every month; Elon already promised that. Will it ever be completely fixed to where it really is great? 

We'll see. How many years you got?

I'm sure someday Grok can create even better lists, but not yet. Until Grok gets hooked up to lists, it's not going to be as good as it needs to be. Once it does, we'll be in a new world. 

I keep hoping that we'll see Grok hooked up to lists‚Äîspecifically a version that can create or expand them‚Äîbut we aren't there yet. Grok (by the way) is not as good as the Levangie Labs' Cognitive Architecture that I'm using to write reports from X. So, we're still a ways away. Maybe a year.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Commentary on X algorithm serving xAI purposes, mentions Levangie Labs Cognitive Architecture being better than Grok for reports
items.reasoning: Insider perspective on Grok limitations, mentions alternative architecture
items.summary_html: Commentary on X algorithm serving xAI purposes, mentions Levangie Labs Cognitive Architecture being better than Grok for reports
items.content_html:
@agentsfy @eliebakouch The algorithm is there to serve the purposes of the xAI Corporation, not us. That's the real truth of the matter.

Fixing it? Yeah, it'll get better every month; Elon already promised that. Will it ever be completely fixed to where it really is great?

We'll see. How many years you got?

I'm sure someday Grok can create even better lists, but not yet. Until Grok gets hooked up to lists, it's not going to be as good as it needs to be. Once it does, we'll be in a new world.

I keep hoping that we'll see Grok hooked up to lists‚Äîspecifically a version that can create or expand them‚Äîbut we aren't there yet. Grok (by the way) is not as good as the Levangie Labs' Cognitive Architecture that I'm using to write reports from X. So, we're still a ways away. Maybe a year.

items.title:
Most companies claim they are becoming AI first.

Almost none understand what that actually requires...
items.content:
Most companies claim they are becoming AI first.

Almost none understand what that actually requires.

The surprising truth: AI does not transform your business by automating existing workflows. It transforms it by replacing deterministic workflows entirely.

I explore this with @hala_zeine, Chief Strategy Officer at @ServiceNow.

#ServiceNowPartner

items.title:
AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

Old software was deterministic. If X t...
items.content:
AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

Old software was deterministic. If X then Y.

AI is probabilistic and pattern unlocking.

This requires leaders to:

‚Üí Reimagine every process, not digitize the old one.
‚Üí Empower every employee with AI capability.
‚Üí Redesign workflows that adapt dynamically to business outcomes instead of rigid rules.

This is a fundamentally different operating model.

items.title:
The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individua...
items.content:
The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individual tools.

The formula is simple: 3 plus 1

1. Define your narrative for the platform, this is the north star for transformation.
2. Measure what you do, and connect metrics directly to value streams.
3. Create a movement, including capability building and governance.
4. The '+1': Prioritize UI/UX, because change sticks only when people pull the technology instead of being pushed into it.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Ronald van Loon outlines '3+1' platform adoption formula: narrative, measurement, movement building, plus UI/UX prioritization
items.reasoning: Change management framework for AI adoption
items.summary_html: Ronald van Loon outlines '3+1' platform adoption formula: narrative, measurement, movement building, plus UI/UX prioritization
items.content_html:
The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individual tools.

The formula is simple: 3 plus 1

1. Define your narrative for the platform, this is the north star for transformation.

2. Measure what you do, and connect metrics directly to value streams.

3. Create a movement, including capability building and governance.

4. The '+1': Prioritize UI/UX, because change sticks only when people pull the technology instead of being pushed into it.

items.content:
The shift to autonomous enterprise starts with a mindset reset.

AI is no longer about task augmentation, it is about role transformation.

We are moving from:

‚Ä¢ People supported by tools
to
‚Ä¢ Personas augmented and partially offloaded to AI agents

This demands that organizations rethink strategy, structure, and culture together.
Not one at a time.

items.title:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People ...
items.content:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People love the idea of change. They just prefer it to happen to someone else.

What works:

‚Üí Leaders who communicate the vision repeatedly.
‚Üí Small teams that are willing to experiment and showcase visible wins.
‚Üí A culture where leaders admit what they know, what they do not know, and what they will figure out together.

AI transformation is a leadership challenge before it becomes a technical one.

items.summary: Discussion of AI adoption barriers - claims fear is biggest blocker, not technology

AI transformation is a leadership challenge before it becomes a technical one.

items.summary_html: GenSpark can create slide decks in 10 minutes, real problem is convincing committees
items.content_html:
@Jessejrlim It doesn't matter; GenSpark can create the slide deck in 10 minutes.

It's the committees that are the problem. It's convincing human beings to do things and get them shipped. It was true 20 years ago when I worked there, and it's still true today.

It's a lot easier to be an independent developer and just put the work on GitHub.

items.title:
And the software stack itself is about to face a reckoning.

20th century architectures cannot keep ...
items.content:
And the software stack itself is about to face a reckoning.

20th century architectures cannot keep up with agentic AI.

They require heart surgery every time a policy, org structure, or product changes.

Winning companies will adopt platforms that separate:

‚Üí Data
‚Üí Business logic
‚Üí Workflows

This creates systems that evolve continuously instead of breaking every quarter.

The vendor relationship shifts from procurement to true partnership.

items.title:
@xuwu You're absolutely right. There is so much magic in VR that has not yet been discovered.

Event...
items.content:
@xuwu You're absolutely right. There is so much magic in VR that has not yet been discovered.

Eventually, we will get:
1. Lighter devices
2. More capable devices
3. Content that's generated by AI (which will be a lot cheaper and better)

And then we'll see where we are. But those days are two to seven years away.

items.title: High end composite flywheel rotors can achieve nearly a kWh/kg of rotational storage when magnetical...
items.content:
High end composite flywheel rotors can achieve nearly a kWh/kg of rotational storage when magnetically levitated in a vacuum chamber. Consider mounting a flywheel in the middle of a wheel, such that magnetically decelerating the flywheel accelerates the wheel. Even if the flywheel was only 1% of the system mass, that is 0.01 kWh/kg, enough energy to accelerate the entire system to 600 mph.

Lots of practical system engineering challenges, and drag would consume more energy, but It would be amusing to outrun a top fuel dragster with a wind up toy.
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack discusses flywheel energy storage physics - high-end composite rotors achieving ~1 kWh/kg when magnetically levitated in vacuum, proposes flywheel-in-wheel concept for 600mph acceleration

items.title: @turbo_xo_ @paulg You should consider the fact that the samples from your personal environment are h...
items.content:
@turbo_xo_ @paulg You should consider the fact that the samples from your personal environment are highly biased.
If you grew up in a poor urban ghetto with lots of immigrants, you might be inclined to think that the crime rate is high among immigrant.
But crime rate is also high in lots of areas with very few immigrants (in rural areas).
And there are many, many immigrants who just work and are law abiding. You just don't see them.

Bottom line: the whole point of the methods used to gather the statistics I mentioned is to minimize the biases. 
That's what the field of statistics is all about: measure stuff properly so you don't fool yourself.

items.title:
First, tell Claude what you want to generate.

Then say: "We're going to go frame-by-frame. Generate...
items.content:
First, tell Claude what you want to generate.

Then say: "We're going to go frame-by-frame. Generate a prompt for the first frame. I will then pass you the image that is generated as a result, and you will write the next prompt for the next frame."

For each prompt, pass it to Nano Banana Pro. When the image is generated, give it to Claude, and ask for the next prompt.

Repeat until you have the frames you need, then have Claude combine them.

It's basically stop motion but with AI!

items.content_html:
@NicolasHoyos_ @timknickmann This is classic moral relativism which fits the "I have no opinions" vibe of most padel players

"Everything is equal" yada yada

It's not, some things are better and some things are worse. Padel is not a real sport, it's not a work out, it doesn't build muscle, it's better than sitting around but only slightly. It's way worse in that it sucks up people's time they could spend doing a sport that actually trains their body like tennis, actual cardio or strength training

The reason Portugal is poor is because the people who rema...
items.content:
@nicolessay @chrisreinberg 100,00000000%

The reason Portugal is poor is because the people who remain in Portugal have 99% no interest in working, getting customers, or showing up on time, or showing p at all!

Which is not completely their fault, the taxes and bureaucracy here for working is so high so why would they

I've met very talented high skilled Portuguese outside Portugal but they all leave and for good reason

My electricians, personal trainer and butcher are great though but those are real exceptions

items.title: Coding agents are changing how software gets built, but most remain closed, expensive, & difficu...
items.content: Coding agents are changing how software gets built, but most remain closed, expensive, & difficult to customize to your codebase. Adapting to codebases has been hard because you need agent-ready synthetic training data, ideally without building complex RL infrastructure.

items.title:
The interesting part is that humans still matter. 

Through LobeHub community, anyone can discover, ...
items.content:
The interesting part is that humans still matter. 

Through LobeHub community, anyone can discover, reuse and remix agent teammates and agent groups ‚Äî customizing them to fit their own workflows and needs. As shown in the video: find a People Search agent in the community, remix the prompt, and swap the tools to level it up. Then you can paste an arXiv link ‚Üí extract authors ‚Üí find contacts ‚Üí send outreach. Useful for VCs, HRs, and sales in talent sourcing.

LobeHub is currently invite-only. Use my invite code ‚Äòlobehub‚Äô to get 2M credits and you‚Äôll also get 2M credits for each referral.

You can find @lobehub here: https://t.co/s5CjbiPgom

And here is the GitHub repo: https://t.co/zcZfK3tzry

items.title: I ran the same benchmark scenario originally demonstrated by Lenny and evaluated it on LobeHub Deskt...
items.content:
I ran the same benchmark scenario originally demonstrated by Lenny and evaluated it on LobeHub Desktop, with help from LobeHub's team. 

The results were on par with Claude Cowork, while LobeHub‚Äôs integrated notebook offered a clearer and more polished visual output. More importantly, thanks to its multi-model architecture, LobeHub was able to complete a video subtitle extraction task that Claude Cowork could not, by assigning the task to Gemini.

items.title: @yasser_elsaid_ We agree. Plus, it would take a thousand meetings at a big company. I used to work a...
items.content:
@yasser_elsaid_ We agree. Plus, it would take a thousand meetings at a big company. I used to work at Microsoft, and doing something like this would involve:

1. Committee after committee
2. Lawyer meeting after lawyer meeting
3. Pointy-haired bosses' meetings
4. Trying to get it funded
5. Getting it through security review
6. Doing consumer research (and waiting for the marketing team to care about it)

Molty is definitely the way to go.

Why I love startups: they can innovate while the big companies can't even get a committee meeting going.
items.author: @Scobleizer

2. Lawyer meeting after lawyer meeting

3. Pointy-haired bosses' meetings

4. Trying to get it funded

5. Getting it through security review

6. Doing consumer research (and waiting for the marketing team to care about it)

Molty is definitely the way to go.

items.title:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People ...
items.content:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People love the idea of change. They just prefer it to happen to someone else.

What works:

‚Üí Leaders who communicate the vision repeatedly.
‚Üí Small teams that are willing to experiment and showcase visible wins.
‚Üí A culture where leaders admit what they know, what they do not know, and what they will figure out together.

AI transformation is a leadership challenge before it becomes a technical one.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Duplicate of fear as AI adoption barrier post
items.summary_html: Duplicate of fear as AI adoption barrier post
items.content_html:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People love the idea of change. They just prefer it to happen to someone else.

What works:

‚Üí Leaders who communicate the vision repeatedly.

‚Üí Small teams that are willing to experiment and showcase visible wins.

‚Üí A culture where leaders admit what they know, what they do not know, and what they will figure out together.

AI transformation is a leadership challenge before it becomes a technical one.

items.title:
AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

Old software was deterministic. If X t...
items.content:
AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

Old software was deterministic. If X then Y.

AI is probabilistic and pattern unlocking.

This requires leaders to:

‚Üí Reimagine every process, not digitize the old one.
‚Üí Empower every employee with AI capability.
‚Üí Redesign workflows that adapt dynamically to business outcomes instead of rigid rules.

This is a fundamentally different operating model.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon

AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

This requires leaders to:

‚Üí Empower every employee with AI capability.

‚Üí Redesign workflows that adapt dynamically to business outcomes instead of rigid rules.

This is a fundamentally different operating model.
